paper_abstract: We show that over fields of characteristic zero there does not exist a polynomial p(n) and a constant-free succinct arithmetic circuit family {Phi(n)} using division by constants,(3) where Phi(n) has size at most p(n) and depth O(1), such that Phi(n) computes the n x n permanent. A circuit family {Phi(n)} is succinct if there exists a nonuniform Boolean circuit family {C-n} with O (log n) many inputs and size n(0(1)) such that C-n can correctly answer direct connection language queries about Phi(n) - succinctness is a relaxation of uniformity. To obtain this result we develop a novel technique that further strengthens the connection between black-box derandomization of polynomial identity testing and lower bounds for arithmetic circuits. From this, we obtain the lower bound by giving an explicit construction, computable in the polynomial hierarchy, of a hitting set for arithmetic circuits. (C) 2012 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
paper_title: Permanent does not have succinct polynomial size arithmetic circuits of constant depth
